question.question-text: It can be inferred from paragraph 1 that, prior to November 2, 1920,

answer-list.answer-text: the results of the presidential election were actually known
other commercial radio broadcasts took place
KDKA was a successful commercial venture

answer-text.exp: there may have been amateur broadcasts

question.explain-text: The passage states that the broadcast on November 2, 1920…is generally considered the first commercial U.S. radio broadcast and mentions wide-ranging efforts in the field of wireless communication in the decades that preceded it. It can be inferred from this that there may have been amateur broadcasts prior to November 2, 1920. The last answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: It can be inferred from paragraph 2 that, prior to the 1870s,

answer-list.answer-text: Maxwell had already conceived the idea for radios
only very basic radios were in use
Marconi was working on developing a radio

question.explain-text: The passage states that the initial concept of wireless communication came about in 1873. It can be inferred from this that, prior to the 1870s, radios did not exist. The second answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: The author mentions these initial stages in paragraph 3 in order to

answer-list.answer-text: initiate a discussion of traditional wired forms of communication
describe an era when wireless communication would have broad-ranging uses

answer-text.exp: relate the ideas in paragraph 3 to those that were presented in paragraph 2

answer-list.answer-text: introduce a discussion of wireless communication after World War I

question.explain-text: The first sentence of paragraph 2 mentions the initial concept, and the first sentence of paragraph 3 mentions these initial stages. From this, it can be determined that the author mentions these initial stages in paragraph 3 to relate the ideas in paragraph 3 to those that were presented in paragraph 2. The third answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: Based on the information in paragraph 3, it can be determined that the military was most likely interested in wireless communication because

answer-text.exp: field units were unable to communicate by means of traditional wired forms of communication

answer-list.answer-text: the military was greatly involved with private shipping
the controversy and competition could be controlled by the military
the military wanted to use wireless communication to broadcast information

question.explain-text: The passage states that wireless communication…quickly caught the interest of the military, which recognized the potential that it provided for communication among rapidly moving military units. From this, it can be determined that the military was most likely interested in wireless communication because field units were unable to communicate by means of traditional wired forms of communication. The first answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: Why does the author mention World War I in paragraph 3?

answer-list.answer-text: It provides one example of the many uses of commercial radio at the time.

answer-text.exp: It represents a point at which a critical change in the development of commercial radio broadcasting occurred.

answer-list.answer-text: It demonstrates how the failure to cooperate led to controversy.
It describes a period when traditional wired forms of communication first came into use.

question.explain-text: The passage states that in the period preceding World War I, there was a considerable amount of controversy and competition among those seeking to garner patents and create business empires using wireless communication and that the cooperation among entrepreneurs in the field of wireless communication that resulted from the war effort led to a sense of cooperation following the war that was beneficial in the further development of the radio industry. From this, it can be determined that the author mentions World War I because it represents a point at which a critical change in the development of commercial radio broadcasting occurred. The second answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: The author mentions the major players in the field in paragraph 4 in order to show that the organizations involved in radio communication

answer-list.answer-text: thought that radios would be used primarily for games
would be able to reach an agreement

answer-text.exp: were taking part in a competitive way

answer-list.answer-text: were interested in broadcasting sports

question.explain-text: The passage states that a short-lived agreement was reached by the major players in the field and that according to the terms of this agreement, American Telephone and Telegraph Company (AT&T) would manufacture radio transmitters, General Electric (GE) and Westinghouse would manufacture radio receivers. From this, it can be determined that the author mentions the major players in the field in order to show that the organizations involved in radio communication were taking part in a competitive way. The third answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: It is implied in paragraph 4 that the 1920 agreement did not last for long because it was based on the idea that

answer-text.exp: radios were to be used to communicate only between one sender and one receiver

answer-list.answer-text: radio broadcasting needed to be implemented as soon as possible
only three companies should be involved in radio broadcasting
radio broadcasting was far more important than individual transmitting and receiving

question.explain-text: The passage states that this agreement, however, was in existence for only a short time because it failed to take into account a new use for radio, that of radio broadcasting. This implies that the 1920 agreement did not last for long because it was based on the idea that radios were to be used to communicate only between one sender and one receiver rather than to broadcast from one sender to many receivers. The first answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: Why does the author mention the "mixing bowl" in paragraph 4?

answer-list.answer-text: To indicate that AT&T, GE, and Westinghouse had merged into one company
To indicate that one of the products sold by RCA would be mixing bowls
To indicate that the information shared by the three companies was rather confusing

answer-text.exp: To create a mental image that RCA represented the combined interests of its three parent companies

question.explain-text: The passage states that the Radio Corporation of America (RCA), which was jointly owned by AT&T, Westinghouse, and GE, would serve as the "mixing bowl" for the products and information for the three companies. From this, it can be determined that the author mentions the "mixing bowl" in order to create a mental image that RCA represented the combined interests of its three parent companies. The last answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: It is implied in paragraph 5 that the earliest conception of radio communication was

answer-text.exp: a single sender communicating with a single receiver

answer-list.answer-text: a single sender communicating with multiple receivers
multiple senders communicating with a single receiver
multiple senders communicating with multiple receivers

question.explain-text: The passage states that this agreement, however, was in existence for only a short time because it failed to take into account a new use for radio, that of radio broadcasting and that the conception of radio communication changed from one of communication between a single sender and a single receiver to one of broadcasting to numerous receivers. It is implied in this that the earliest conception of radio communication was a single sender communicating with a single receiver. The first answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: The author mentions a Pittsburgh department store in paragraph 5 in order to show that the development of commercial radio broadcasting was enabled because broadcasting

answer-list.answer-text: could take place in department stores
required receivers to be installed at stores

answer-text.exp: offered opportunities to other commercial ventures

answer-list.answer-text: could be promoted during sales at stores

question.explain-text: The passage states that KDKA was started as an amateur operation by Frank Conrad, that his broadcasts…increased in popularity when a Pittsburgh department store began promoting Conrad's broadcasts by selling radio receivers to pick up the broadcasts, that Westinghouse…began promoting the sales of its own receivers, and that Westinghouse filed an application for a commercial license for KDKA. From this, it can be determined that the author mentions a Pittsburgh department store in order to show that the development of radio broadcasting was enabled because it offered opportunities to other commercial ventures. The third answer is therefore the best answer to this question.
